titleStmt.title: Description of Free Library of Philadelphia, Lewis E 1: De amore et dilectione Dei (On the love and favor of God); De doctrina dicendi et tacendi (On the doctrine of speaking and keeping silent); De ritu et moribus Indorum (On the rites and ways of the Indians); Historia de preliis Alexandri Magni (History of the battles of Alexander the Great); Pseudo-Sibylline Prophecy; Sermones quattuor (Four sermons)
titleStmt.funder: Council on Library and Information Resources

notesStmt.note: Increasing wormhole damage toward end of manuscript

Sotheby, Wilkinson, and Hodge, Catalogue of a Magnificent Collection of Manuscripts formed by a gentleman of consummate taste and judgment…which will be sold by auction by Messrs. Sotheby, Wilkinson & Hodge, at their house, No.13 Wellington Street, on Wednesday, the 7th June, 1876, and Three following Days, lot 2.
Ricci, Seymour de, with the assistance of W. J. Wilson, Census of Medieval and Renaissance Manuscripts in the United States and Canada, vol. 2 (New York: H. W. Wilson, 1935-40), p. 2051, no. 144.

Free Library of Philadelphia, A Descriptive Catalogue of the John Frederick Lewis Collection of European Manuscripts in the Free Library of Philadelphia, compiled by Edwin Wolf, 2nd, with an introduction by Dr. A.S.W. Rosenbach (Philadelphia: The Library, 1937), p. 1-3, no. 1.

Rosenbach Museum and Library, Sixty Bokes Olde and Newe: Manuscripts and Early Printed Books from Libraries in and Near Philadelphia Illustrating Chaucer's Sources, His Works and their Influence, exhibition catalogue. (Knoxville, TN: New Chaucer Society, 1986), pp. 75-77, no. 42.

msIdentifier.collection: John Frederick Lewis Collection of European Manuscripts

msContents.summary: This late thirteenth-century Italian manuscript brings together several treatises and sermons of Albertano da Brescia, followed by Archipresbyter Leo's history of Alexander the Great and the epistle on India attributed to Prester John. It is written in early Italian rotunda script and illuminated with initials and marginal illustrations in a palette of dark blue, light blue, orange, pink, and cream.

msItem.title: De amore et dilectione Dei (On the love and favor of God); De doctrina dicendi et tacendi (On the doctrine of speaking and keeping silent); De ritu et moribus Indorum (On the rites and ways of the Indians); Historia de preliis Alexandri Magni (History of the battles of Alexander the Great); Pseudo-Sibylline Prophecy; Sermones quattuor (Four sermons)
msItem.author: Albertano, da Brescia, active 13th century
Leo, Archipresbyter, active 10th century

msItem.title: Albertano da Brescia, Liber de doctrina dicendi et tacendi
Albertano da Brescia, Liber consolationis et consilii
Albertano da Brescia, De amore et dilectione
Prester John, De ritu et moribus Indorum

supportDesc.extent: ii+100+ii; 265 x 180 mm bound to 270 x 185 mm
supportDesc.foliation: Modern foliation in pencil, upper right recto

p.catchwords: Lower right corner or center lower margin of last verso, quires 1-8, several partially trimmed

layoutDesc.layout: Two columns of fifty-one lines; ruled in lead point; written area: 76 x 108 mm

decoDesc.decoNote: One large historiated initial with Saint James the Apostle and a soldier (fol.1r), decorated initials throughout, marginal decoration and figures (especially birds) throughout; between fols. 76r-82r are eighteen blank spaces of eight to twenty-four lines, each preceding a new chapter, possibly reserved for column miniatures
1rHistoriated initial I with Saint James the Apostle and a soldier, inhabited marginal extensions
28vMarginal illustration, Cupid with bow and arrow
57rDecorated Man and snail in the margin
60rMarginal illustration, Fox and crane from Aesop's Fables
60rDecorated bird and wolf in the margin
61vDecorated Man and wolf in the margin
62vDecorated creature with man's head in the margin
74vInhabited initial I, Bust-length figure of a man

binding.p: Nineteenth-century brown morocco, black tooled, by Townsend of Suffolk

history.provenance: William Bragge, Birmingham, England, his sale 7 June 1876, lot 2; John Frederick Lewis, Philadelphia; given by his widow, Anne Baker Lewis, to the Free Library of Philadelphia in 1936
